intro: Gilia nudata, commonly known as the naked-stem gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, often hairless stems and clusters of small, showy flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Gilia nudata is a member of the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) and is often found in open areas with well-drained soils.
